description:
This PR updates and adds to the callback functionality.  

It adds the `annotate_scale()` callback to enable to the user to overplot the size scale of the plot in either user-specified distance units, or if None are specified, it figures out a good value.  This means it works well in generating movies from `TimeSeries` data to always show the current scale of the plot in reasonable units.

It updates the font backend of the callbacks, so that all callbacks using text will use the font characteristics set for the rest of the PlotWindow.  This means that using p.set_font() will update *all* of the text in a plot, including the callbacks.

It updates the `annotate_timestamp()` callback to enable the user to overplot redshift and/or time information, with a variable format/precision, and provides several sensible defaults for location, size, etc.  It retains all of the old functionality, but there are a few minor changes in the syntax:

Old syntax:

```
#!python

annotate_timestamp(x, y, units=None, format="{time:.3G} {units}", **kwargs, normalized=False, bbox_dict=None)
```

New syntax:


```
#!python

annotate_timestamp(corner='lowerleft', time=True, redshift=False, time_format='t = {time:.0f} {units}', time_unit=None, redshift_format='z = {redshift:.2f}', bbox=False, pos=None, text_args=None, bbox_args=None)
```

I've added tests for the two new callbacks, docstrings, and entries on the Plot Modifications docs page.

For a demonstration of how to use these new features, see this notebook:
[http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/anonymous/3bd06d3805b75d307413]()

UPDATE1: Accounted for all comments from @ngoldbaum as well as those from the yt-dev discussion.  Modified API of annotate_timestamp() to have `x_pos` and `y_pos` kwargs as the first kwargs so as to minimize problems with API switch.  Integrated time information into `get_smallest_appropriate_unit()` so it now works with time units.  Cleaned up exceptions, updated docs, etc.
UPDATE2: Accounting for all comments from @ngoldbaum .  Changing `bbox` references to be `inset_box`, making docstring tests, and more docstring examples.  Correcting minor text errors.
UPDATE3: Correcting a typo that caused an error in the docs cookbook tests.
UPDATE4: Correcting a typo that caused an error in the tests.
title: [BREAKS_API] Updating callbacks to include: annotate_timestamp, annotate_scale, and make callbacks use same font as other plot text

pullrequest.title: [BREAKS_API] Updating callbacks to include: annotate_timestamp, annotate_scale, and make callbacks use same font as other plot text

content.raw: Can you call this keyword argument `draw_inset_box` - I think that's clearer.  Usually in matplotlib a `bbox` is something somewhat more general than what you're talking about here.  Similarly `bbox_args` below should be `inset_box_properties`, or something like that.
content.html: Can you call this keyword argument draw_inset_box - I think that's clearer. Usually in matplotlib a bbox is something somewhat more general than what you're talking about here. Similarly bbox_args below should be inset_box_properties, or something like that.

pullrequest.title: [BREAKS_API] Updating callbacks to include: annotate_timestamp, annotate_scale, and make callbacks use same font as other plot text

content.raw: Can you add an example that doesn't use `redshift=True`?  Many datasets don't have a notion of a redshift and I want to make it clear that this will still work in those cases.
content.html: Can you add an example that doesn't use redshift=True? Many datasets don't have a notion of a redshift and I want to make it clear that this will still work in those cases.

content.raw:
It would be nice to have a cookbook recipe for each of the new callbacks so you can go into a little bit more detail explaining all the options.  You could base it off of the notebook you've attached to the PR description.

I think this is a significant improvement.  There's definitely some iteration and discussion that needs to happen before this goes in, but this is a great start. Great work!
content.html:
It would be nice to have a cookbook recipe for each of the new callbacks so you can go into a little bit more detail explaining all the options. You could base it off of the notebook you've attached to the PR description.

I think this is a significant improvement. There's definitely some iteration and discussion that needs to happen before this goes in, but this is a great start. Great work!

pullrequest.title: [BREAKS_API] Updating callbacks to include: annotate_timestamp, annotate_scale, and make callbacks use same font as other plot text

content.raw: There needs to be a space at the end of this line, otherwise the bit at the end of this line and the beginning of the next will get rendered as `to'upper_left'`.  In addition the trailing backslashes here (and elsewhere in this PR) are unnecessary since you're inside enclosing parens.
content.html: There needs to be a space at the end of this line, otherwise the bit at the end of this line and the beginning of the next will get rendered as to'upper_left'. In addition the trailing backslashes here (and elsewhere in this PR) are unnecessary since you're inside enclosing parens.

pullrequest.title: [BREAKS_API] Updating callbacks to include: annotate_timestamp, annotate_scale, and make callbacks use same font as other plot text

content.raw: The existing behavior is actually incorrect, since if you pass `YTQuantity(1., 'kpc')` to `get_smallest_appropriate_unit()`, you'll get out `pc` instead of `kpc`.  I was correcting this in addition to the other changes I made incorporating Time units and the powers of 10.
content.html: The existing behavior is actually incorrect, since if you pass YTQuantity(1., 'kpc') to get_smallest_appropriate_unit(), you'll get out pc instead of kpc. I was correcting this in addition to the other changes I made incorporating Time units and the powers of 10.

pullrequest.title: [BREAKS_API] Updating callbacks to include: annotate_timestamp, annotate_scale, and make callbacks use same font as other plot text

content.raw: I missed it in your first set of comments, but in reviewing this, I still think that `bbox` is still appropriate.  I was actually only adapting it from the previous `annotate_timestamp()` function, where it was first used.  That said, it is a bounding box around the text in the same way MPL uses it (and the same way we use it elsewhere in yt).
content.html: I missed it in your first set of comments, but in reviewing this, I still think that bbox is still appropriate. I was actually only adapting it from the previous annotate_timestamp() function, where it was first used. That said, it is a bounding box around the text in the same way MPL uses it (and the same way we use it elsewhere in yt).

pullrequest.title: [BREAKS_API] Updating callbacks to include: annotate_timestamp, annotate_scale, and make callbacks use same font as other plot text

content.raw: Right, I just think that `bbox` is a bit more of a general bounding box in matplotlib, while this is specifically an inset box, and I want to make that clear.
content.html: Right, I just think that bbox is a bit more of a general bounding box in matplotlib, while this is specifically an inset box, and I want to make that clear.

pullrequest.title: [BREAKS_API] Updating callbacks to include: annotate_timestamp, annotate_scale, and make callbacks use same font as other plot text

content.raw: I started changing this, and as I did so, it just seems more confusing to describe it as an `inset box`.  It is a box that bounds the timestamp text.  It's creating a MPL `FancyBboxPatch` object by running the MPL `text()` function using the MPL `bbox` keyword.  Unless there are others who think this should be switched to the `inset_box` syntax, I would like to keep it as `bbox` as I think that best describes it.
content.html: I started changing this, and as I did so, it just seems more confusing to describe it as an inset box. It is a box that bounds the timestamp text. It's creating a MPL FancyBboxPatch object by running the MPL text() function using the MPL bbox keyword. Unless there are others who think this should be switched to the inset_box syntax, I would like to keep it as bbox as I think that best describes it.
